topic.title: Adding Labels to Topics in the WebHelp Responsive output

body.p: DITA topics can contain keyword elements usually placed in a prolog element. <topic id="topicID"> <title>DITA 1.3 Features</title> <prolog> <metadata> <keywords> <keyword>DITA 1.3</keyword> </keywords> </metadata> </prolog>...The Oxygen WebHelp responsive output uses these keywords as a way to give more priority to certain sequences words when searching for content in order to locate the specific topics. Keywords do not appear by default in the published output.

This article is an attempt to add a new concept of label, a label being a keyword which is visible in the published output and which when pressed displays all other topics which have the same label set to them.

section.title: Inserting Labels
section.p: We can decide to use the DITA keyword element with a certain outputclass attribute value set to label to insert such keywords which should be displayed in the published output.<topic id="topicID"> <title>DITA 1.3 Features</title> <prolog> <metadata> <keywords> <keyword outputclass="label">DITA 1.3</keyword> </keywords> </metadata> </prolog>...
To make the insertion of such labels easier you can for example create a custom Author action which inserts labels and add it to the content completion window: .
To have special styling for the inserted labels when editing you can customize the CSS stylesheets used for DITA editing:

section.title: Taking labels into account when publishing
section.p:
DITA WebHelp output can be customized using a publishing template mechanism. Inside a publishing template folder there is an opt file which can contain links to various XSLT stylesheets useful for customizations, we'll add a link to a stylesheet for processing such special keyword label elements: ..... ...... .... ..... The labels-show.xsl stylesheet will match all labels and display them after the title of each topic. For each label it will have a link to search in the entire documentation for the same label:
Labels:
,
The end result displays labels defined in each topic and allows you to click on each label and find all topics with the same label.
